NOU, Munger varsity VCs to deliver lectu.description: PATNA: Nalanda Open University vice-chancellor (VC) Ravindra Kumar Sinha left for China on Tuesday to participate in an international conference on ‘Persistent, Bioaccumulative, Toxic Substances’ being organized by Harbin Institute of Technology from June 21 to 23. Sinha, a noted environmentalist, will talk about ‘Toxic Substances in the Ganga’ on June 22 and chair a scientific session the same day. He will also deliver lectures on ‘Impact of Climate Change on Human Health and Natural Resources’, ‘Biodiversity and Sustainable Development’, ‘Management of River Ecosystem: A Case Study of River Ganga’ as well as ‘Ecosystem Goods and Services’. Sinha had been invited to deliver lectures at international conferences held in Sri Lanka, Malaysia, Bangkok and China last year. Meanwhile, Munger University VC Ranjit Kumar Verma reached Budapest on Tuesday to deliver a lecture at a joint international thermoanalytical conference convened by Hungary, Poland, Czechoslovakia and Slovakia from June 18 to 20. Verma, who is also a member of the international scientific committee of the conference, will chair a session on June 20. In his lecture, he will focus on the thermo-oxidative decomposition of mustard oil, which is not suitable for use at high temperature. He will also demonstrate how use of turmeric slows down such decomposition and reduces the harmful effects. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Mahagathbandhan.description: NEW DELHI: Taking a swipe at the grand alliance of opposition parties, finance minister Arun Jaitley on Friday said the 'mahagathbandhan' is a 'non-bandhan', political circus and a recipe for chaos. Several political parties, mostly traditional BJP opponents, have come together to take on the National Democratic Alliance (NDA) in the ensuing general elections beginning April 11. In a blog post, Jaitley said that over the last several months, India was "exhausted" with the talk of a 'Mahagathbandhan'. The rationale, he said, was that Prime Minister Narendra Modi and the BJP were very strong and could not be challenged by individual party. Stressing that Indians judge politicians by their merit and capacity and no longer by any traditional loyalty, he said: "We were promised a 'coalition of rivals' because India had to be saved. We were promised a common minimum agenda. Each leader amongst the aspirant Prime Ministers wanted to become a 'sutradhar' (anchor) of the alliance. He/she would periodically organise shows in his/her State and invite the entire bandwagon." In opposition camp, Jaitley said there is a tussle for leadership as already multiple candidates have made their desire clear to take over the mantle of the leadership. According to him, each one of them is interested to see the strength of the other party's contender depleting and also have high hopes in a chaotic and highly hung Parliament. "He/ she believes that only in a chaotic situation he/she has a chance," said Jaitley, who is heading the BJP's publicity division of the seven-phase Lok Sabha elections. The past track record of such governments in terms of policy, longevity and growth has to be borne in mind, he said adding their track record of corruption is equally well-known. Jaitley further said it is only because of the size of the BJP and clarity on leadership in the last coalition that a successful government was run under Prime Minister Modi. "Today you have no 'gathbandhan' let alone 'mahagathbandhan'. It is a 'non-bandhan'. You have no leader, no programme, no meeting of minds. "Stability, which is paramount, is a major casualty. The only thing in common is negative agenda 'remove one man'. It is a recipe for chaos," he said in the blog titled 'A Political Circus Called 'Mahagathbandhan'. The nominations for the first two phases of polling are over and those for the third phase are about to happen. The results will be announced on May 23. BJP List 2019 Karnataka.description: BENGALURU: The BJP on Thursday released its first list of 21 candidates from Karnataka, but it does not include the names of sitting MP Karadi Sanganna (Koppal) or late Union minister HN Ananth Kumar’s wife Tejaswini, who is widely tipped to be the candidate from Bengaluru South. The list names the 14 other sitting MPs, including Shobha Karandlaje (Udupi-Chikkamagalur) and Suresh Angadi (Belagavi) despite stiff opposition within the party and anti-incumbency against the two. Party leaders said they are baffled by the exclusion of Tejaswini’s name and are unaware of the reasons for her candidature being withheld. “We inaugurated her personal office on Thursday and were sure of her name being announced,” one leader said. Rumours — from “technical” errors to the possibility that her name would lead to comments on “dynasty politics” — are doing the rounds. Sanganna’s candidature was withheld as the BJP is waiting for the JD(S)-Congress coalition to name its candidate. With the possibility of former chief minister Siddaramaiah contesting, the BJP will require a stronger candidate. The party also decided not to announce its candidate for Mandya, but two Congress rebels — A Manju from Hassan and Umesh Jadhav from Kalaburagi — have been given tickets. BSY has his wayThe first list confirms that the BJP central leadership continues to repose faith in state party president and Lingayat strongman BS Yeddyurappa. The list features names of his son BY Raghavendra and several confidants. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

4k students from city to write NET.description: PATNA: Over 4,000 candidates from Patna will appear for UGC NET-2019 (National Eligibility Test), which will be conducted by the National Testing Agency in two shifts from June 20 to 28. The exam determines the eligibility for college and university-level lectureship and for the award of Junior Research Fellowship. Admit cards were released on May 28 and results of the test are likely to published on July 15. It will be conducted in 84 subjects at 91 different cities across the country. The subjects are selected as per the students’ choice. Kankerbagh resident Abhishek Rath (28), who is pursuing MA in journalism from Banaras Hindu University, told this newspaper, “This is my first attempt. If I score well, I will choose a reputed university like Indian Institute of Mass Communication or Jawaharlal Nehru University.” Chemistry teacher Tanuja Sharma will write NET for the second time on Thursday. “I am a schoolteacher and hope to crack the exam this time,” she said. NET comprises two papers — I and II — which have multiple-choice questions to test reasoning ability, comprehension, divergent thinking and general awareness. There is no negative marking in the test. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

\nJustice Ajay Tripathi attends golf tou.description: The prize distribution and dinner of a recently-concluded golf tournament provided the perfect bahana to city folk to catch up with friends and socialize over some good food and drinks.  Post the prize distribution ceremony, in which Aman, Alok Sahi, Arif Hussain and Bilkis Jahan were announced the winners, the guests lined up to congratulate them, as well as learn a few golf tips. Yashi earned a lot of compliments for her putting skills.  Among the early birds at the party were Justice Ajay Tripathi, Tuheen Shankar and Awnish Rana. Nandita Sahi looked simple and pretty in her white suit. Shraddha Sahay, who came all the way from Delhi to participate in the tournament, was spotted enjoying the do with her friends. Mohit Ahluwalia was there with son-in-law Purusendra and daughter Shaheena. Rudrani and Poonam spent quite some time posing for pictures. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Muzzafarpur Encephalitis deaths: Nitish.description: MUZAFFARPUR: RJD leader Raghuvansh Prasad Singh on Wednesday said that Bihar chief minister Nitish Kumar should resign from his post on moral grounds over the death of over 100 children Muzaffarpur due to Acute Encephalitis Syndrome (AES). "The one who has the steering in his hands, shouldn't he run the vehicle properly? The steering is in chief minister's hands. Then who else will be held responsible for this. He (Nitish Kumar) should himself resign on the basis of morality. Since many years, they couldn't find a cure to this disease and maintain the hospitals. Also, they didn't fulfill whatever they promised," Singh told ANI here. "The state government is responsible for this. Since last 15-20 years, children have been dying because of this. But who takes note of the deaths in rural areas? Around 300-400 children have died there. Secondly, every year specialists come here but it has not been found yet why this disease is breaking out. Somebody said it is because of litchi fruit, while the other said it is because of heat wave," he added. Singh criticised the facilities provided at SKMCH for patients and said, "There are no basic facilities provided in hospital... SKMCH is hell. People can't walk in the hospital without covering nose. No bed, no fans, no water... doctors are doing their jobs as per the facilities provided to them. They have kept three people on one bed. Around 200-250 patients are lying there on the floor. There can't be more shameful than the state government claiming that everything is alright." Asked about RJD leader Tejashwi Yadav, Singh said, "I don't know exactly where he is. Maybe he has gone to watch the World Cup. I am not sure about it." Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

\nAddy performs at the annual cultural f.description: IIT-Patna’sannual cultural fest, Anwesha 2015, concluded recently after four days of mind-blowing music and lots of masti. Events like the dance competition and fashion show provided the perfect dose of entertainment at the fest. Day one of the fest started on a musical note with Samarjit Mukherjee, an Indian classical guitarist, mesmerising the audience with his music, followed by a performance by Swarathma, a Bengaluru-based band. Verve, the fashion show and hand shadowgraphy by Amarsen and Sabyasachi Sen were the highlights of the second day. Day three was reserved for some hardcore dancing. The The flash mob of NIFT Patna entertained the crowd with their energetic dance performance on the song Blue Eyes. A loud cheer rang out from the crowd when Deepanjali danced on the song Hamma Hamma. The last evening of the fest saw the band Lagori from Bengaluru performing live for the students. They belted out songs like Dama Dam Mast Qalandar and Main Tenu Samjhawaan Ki, providing a rocking finale to the fest.Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Urmila Matondkar.description: MUMBAI: The Congress on Friday nominated actress Urmila Matondkar and former Lok Sabha speaker Meira Kumar from Mumbai North and Bihar's Sasaram parliamentary constituencies respectively. The party renominated its sitting MP Ranjet Ranjan from Supaul in Bihar, as it released a list of another 12 candidates for the general elections. With this list, the Congress has so far nominated 305 Lok Sabha candidates. Urmila Matondkar to contest from Mumbai North parliamentary constituency on a Congress ticket.… https://t.co/JweKWNh1FN— ANI (@ANI) 1553836382000It also changed its candidate in Uttar Pradesh's Maharajganj by now fielding Supriya Shrinate in place of Tanushree Tripathi, the daughter of jailed politician Amarmani Tripathi, after facing widespread criticism. "The Congress central election committee has approved the candidature of Urmila Matondkar as party candidate to contest the ensuing general elections from Mumbai North parliamentary constituency in Maharashtra," a party statement said. Matondkar had joined the Congress after meeting Rahul Gandhi on Wednesday and had later said that she was "here to stay". Meira Kumar have been contesting from her Sasaram parliamentary constituency for many years but had lost in the 2014 Lok Sabha polls. Apart from Supriya Shrinate, in the list of 12 candidates released by the party, four are from Bihar and seven from Odisha. The Congress also released a list of 20 candidates for Odisha Assembly election. Patna HC: Paperwork won\u2019t solve enc.description: PATNA: The Patna high court on Tuesday came down heavily on the state government for dealing with the issue of massive encroachments by vendors on several city roads “only on papers” instead of finding a permanent solution. The Patna high court division bench of Chief Justice Amreshwar Pratap Sahi and Justice Anjana Mishra made the verbal remark while hearing a public interest litigation (PIL) filed by Vikash Chandra alias Guddu Baba. The court, while taking strong exception to the issue, suggested the authorities concerned to settle the vendors encroaching upon public roads in front of the residences of ministers so that people could be spared of their sufferings. The petitioner had urged the court to direct the authorities concerned to get rid of roadside encroachments on Ashok Rajpath, Bari Path, Hathua and Lalji markets and the stretch between Pataliputra Colony and Digha road. These encroachments, according to the petitioner, lead to massive traffic snarls in the city. The high court asked the state government to file a counter affidavit by Monday, informing it about the current status of construction of vending zones and settlement of roadside encroachers. The court slammed the government for reappearance of encroachers on roads due to lack of proper vending zones for them. The issue of illegal settlement made below Rajendra Nagar overbridge by the then Patna DM U K Sinha on July 22, 1988, also surfaced during Tuesday’s hearing. The high court had directed the state government to file a reply on the issue on January 15 this year. Patna DM, who filed a counter affidavit on behalf of chief secretary, informed the court that the state government had ordered removal of those living below the bridge at a meeting held recently. Sinha had allowed 214 people to live below the bridge in 1988. The court asked the government to mention in its affidavit the detailed plan regarding eviction of those living below the bridge and their settlement. Additional advocate generals Prabhat Kumar Verma and Prasoon Sinha appeared for the state government and Patna Municipal Corporation, respectively, in the court. Youngsters learn more about social media.description: An interactive session was organised by Patna Diaries at a posh cafe to discuss social media and its various usage. Irfan, the convener of the event, shared many information on the right ways to use social media sites. Interacting with the participants, he said, “I am grateful to all the young participants, including food bloggers, youtubers, photographers, social workers and web developers of the city. There are many techniques to expand and spread the reach of social media profiles, which will benefit everyone.” Sharing similar views, Alfaaz, a member of the organisation, said, “The main objective of this session was to learn the use of the internet in a clear and correct manner. Social media is a powerful and an effective tool. If it is used properly, we can make a good image of any of our brands.” Participants liked the session and they also shared their views on it. Aditya Vaibhav, a digital marketing professional, said, “The session was really very informative. There were many things which we usually miss. But after today’s session, we know how to explore them to have a wider reach. This will make our lives much easier.” Kumari Slish, another participant, said, “I am glad to be a part of this event as I have learnt a lot about the use of various social media platforms. I was really looking forward to this event. This will help me in various ways, especially my work. Some of the basic tips are actually very effective and creative. I will definitely try it.” Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

All departments to have a finance sectio.description: PATNA: All the state government departments would now have a finance section to be headed by an officer of Bihar Finance Service (BFS). The state government on Tuesday took a decision to depute at least one BFS officer in each department to take care of financial issues, said deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi after the review meeting of the finance department by CM Nitish Kumar. Modi, who also holds the finance portfolio, said with the introduction of Comprehensive Finance Management System (CFMS), all financial transactions in the state government has become online and different offices of finance department have become ‘paperless’. As the result, nearly 100 BFS officers who were earlier deputed in different treasuries, have become redundant. The government decided to open finance section in each department to utilize the services of these officers. He said the State Bank of India (SBI) was earlier working as ‘agency bank’ in the state. Now, the SBI has no role to play in transaction of salaries in the bank account of state government employees. He said salaries in the employees’ bank accounts were being transferred directly from the Reserve Bank of India after introduction of the CFMS. Speaking at the review meeting, the CM stressed the need for better financial management in the state and asked the finance department to be prepared to take additional ‘liabilities’ in the wake of people’s growing aspirations and demands. “Peoples’ income in the state is increasing. The purchasing power of even middle class people has increased. The market status has improved a lot across the state. These are indicators of economic progress. In such a scenario, the finance department should be ready to take additional liabilities.” Earlier, principal secretary (finance) S Siddharth made a PowerPoint presentation before the CM about different steps taken by the department for better financial management. State’s chief secretary Deepak Kumar and development commissioner Subhash Sharma were also present in the review meeting. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

BSP List 2019 UP.description: LUCKNOW: The BSP on Friday announced its first list of 11 candidates for the Lok Sabha elections 2019, fielding JD(S) turncoat Kunwar Danish Ali from Amroha. Ali, who was general secretary of the Janata Dal-Secular, quit the party and joined the Bahujan Samaj Party only last week. The BSP also declared Haji Fazulrahman its nominee from Saharanpur, Malook Nagar from Bijnore and Girish Chandra from Nagina, a party release said. Hazi Mohammad Yakoob has been fielded from Meerut, Satbeer Nagar from Gautam Buddh Nagar, Yogesh Verma from Bulandshahr, Ajit Baliyan from Aligarh, Manoj Kumar Soni from Agra, Rajveer Singh from Fatehpur Sikri and Ruchi Veera from Aonla. Mayawati's BSP is contesting 38 of the 80 Lok Sabha constituencies in Uttar Pradesh under the seat-sharing arrangement with Samajwadi Party and the Rashtriya Lok Dal. PM Modi.description: JEYPORE: Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Friday said his government had taken measures to set up a 'chowkidar' in space and asked people to vote for a government that can take concrete decisions and not just raise slogans. Launching his campaign in eastern India with a rally in Jeypore area of Odisha's Koraput district, the prime minister said the NDA government wouldn't have been able to do any development work in the country without the support of the people. He sought blessings from his supporters for the 2019 Lok Sabha elections and asserted that the NDA government has left no stone unturned to bring about development in the state. Land, air or space, we had courage to do surgical strikes: PM Modi"The NDA government has been working hard to develop road and rail infrastructure in the state. There is no dearth of funds when it comes to development work in the country. "In the last five years, the government has been able to build homes for eight lakh families, light up 3,000 houses and provide gas connections to 40 lakh homes," Modi stated. Referring to Mission Shakti, when India demonstrated anti-satellite (ASAT) missile capability by shooting down a live satellite, he said the government has taken measures to set up a 'chowkidar' (watchman) in space. He came down heavily on opposition parties who he said "belittled" the space achievement. "Those that are criticising the anti-satellite technology will be given a befitting reply in the elections," he claimed, urging people to vote for a government that can take concrete decisions, not the one that only raises slogans. Satta Matka 2018.description: AGRA: Shyam Vohra, known as 'satta king' of the Taj city, was denied bail by district court of Agra. Vohra, who was arrested by the Agra police in July for his alleged involvement in betting on FIFA World Cup matches. Earlier, in April, Vohra was arrested by the Nodia STF from Greater Noida for placing bets on IPL matches, but he was granted bail. After Vohra’s arrest, Agra police booked him and his known associates including his son Vatsal, wife Rakhi, nephew Prateek, brother-in-law Kaushal and others for their alleged involvement in betting. On Monday, judge Anil Kumar Pundhir rejected Vohra’s bail plea, who was charged for attempt to murder, as he allegedly opened fire on policemen. Further, Vohra was charged for running illegal gambling racket, criminal conspiracy and obstructing policemen from executing their duties. Police are yet to arrest the relatives and associates of Vohra. Several years back, Vohra had gain notoriety for betting on cricket matches. In April, during IPL matches, the gambling racket run by Vohra had deposited Rs 62 lakh in 10 banks, after which police approached banks to freeze the amount. Even during the FIFA World Cup, Vohra collected huge amount of cash through betting. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Bihar government on receiving end of opp.description: PATNA: The Nitish Kumar government is on the receiving end of not only the opposition parties but also some ruling BJP leaders over the deaths due to acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) in Bihar. RJD is to take out a candle march from Kargil Chowk to Mahatma Gandhi’s statue in Gandhi Maidan on Thursday while its student wing will stage a protest march to Raj Bhavan on Sunday and hold demonstrations at all the district headquarters on Monday. State Congress has asked the government to declare the deaths due to AES as national disaster. “When deaths by tsunami, fire and thunderstorm can be included in national disaster, why not AES as children are dying because they are malnourished,” said Anand Madhab, who was state Congress manifesto and research committee chairman. Congress had staged a candle march in Patna on Tuesday. He also took a jibe at state health minister Mangal Pandey and Union minister of state for health and family welfare Ashwini Kumar Choubey and said, “One was asking cricket score and the other was sleeping during the press conference. This is their seriousness. Health system in the state is in pathetic condition”. He also said the government should incorporate more private hospitals under the Ayushman Bharat scheme so that the poor could get proper treatment. “Excess pressure on Sri Krishna Medical College and Hospital (SKMCH) has also exposed the facilities at primary health centres in the state,” he said. RJD national vice-president Rabri Devi hit out at central and state governments saying instead of investing Rs500 crore on advertisements to prove good governance, they should have used the money on medicine and beds in hospitals. The former Bihar CM asked whether the double-engine government had the capability to bring kids to the state capital for better treatment. BJP’s Rajya Sabha member and former Union health minister Dr C P Thakur also criticised the Nitish government for its failure to tackle the situation since the outbreak of AES, which has claimed over 100 lives so far. “The government comes into active mode only at the time of the outbreak, while measures should have been taken beforehand to prevent the crisis. The government needs to take the situation seriously and focus on research so that such diseases do not affect people in future,” Dr Thakur said in a press statement issued earlier this week. HAM (S) chief Jitan Ram Manjhi said the government machinery became active only after deaths were reported. He also hit out at Union health minister Harsh Vardhan for not fulfilling the promises made by him during his visit to Muzaffarpur in 2014 when the situation was similar. Manjhi even lambasted the state government for spending money on construction of Bihar Museum, convention centre and Buddha Park, but ignoring health infrastructure. Prime Minister Narendra Modi hosted the main event in Ranchi and performed yoga along with 18,000 people. It was on September 27, 2014 that PM Modi proposed a dedicated day for Yoga to the United Nations General Assembly (UNGA). In 2015, the first International Day of Yoga was observed. Here's a look at different yoga styles and its growing popularity worldwide. Download The Times of India News App for Latest India News.

DGP suspends Naugachhia cop for derelict.description: BHAGALPUR: DGP Gupteshwar Pandey, who made a surprise visit to carious police stations under Naugachia and Bhagalpur districts on Thursday, suspended Rangra police outpost in charge and directed to shift all policemen posted at Rangra PS under Naugachia police district to Police Lines for not updating their case diaries and dereliction of duty. During the surprise inspection, the DGP visited the Naugachia Town police station, Mahila police station and SC/ST police station among others and found many policemen lax and not keeping keeping their station dairies updated. Senior officials said the surprise visit of DGP came in the backdrop of CM Nitish Kumar’s recent review meeting on to law and order situation. The CM is scheduled to hold another review meeting on law and order on June 25. Naugachia SP Nidhi Rani said, “The DGP has issued instructions for taking strong action against the criminals in the area and disposal of cases within the stipulated time frame. He has also asked to keep the station diaries updated,” added the SP. The DGP also reviewed the law and order situation in Bhagalpur with SSP Ashish Bharti and other senior officers including DIG Vikas Vaibhav. Directing the Bhagalpur SSP and other officials to take strong measures against criminals and anti-social elements, the DGP asked them to remain vigilant and take quick action. He also directed to dispose of the cases, execute warrants and take measures to arrest the absconders and criminals. He also reviewed the status of some of the sensitive cases, including the killing of an intermediate schoolgirl, who was doused with acid by a gang of youths at her house in Aliganj under Babarganj police station in Bhagalpur on April 19. BJP List 2019 Tamilnadu.description: CHENNAI: The BJP's Tamil Nadu candidates list announced on Thursday was on expected lines, with Union minister Pon Radhakrishnan being fielded from Kanyakumari, state chief Tamilisai Soundararajan in Tuticorin, national secretary H Raja in Sivaganga, C P Radhakrishnan in Coimbatore and vice-president Nainar Nagendran in Ramanathapuram. While Pon Radhakrishnan and Raja will fight Congress, which is yet to name candidates for its nine seats in DMK alliance, Tamilisai will cross swords with DMK heavyweight Kanimozhi in Tuticorin. H Raja to contest from Sivaganga for third timeH Raja is contesting from Sivaganga for the third time. In 2014, he came third with 1.33 lakh votes, while in 1999, he came second. It will be a keenly fought battle between Tamilisai and DMK’s state women wing secretary and Rajya Sabha MP K Kanimozhi in Tuticorin. Though Tamilisai initially preferred to contest from Chennai South, which has a sizeable votebank for the party, she finally settled for Tuticorin. AIADMK was keen on retaining south Chennai for sitting MP, J Jayavardhan, son of fisheries minister D Jayakumar. Former TN BJP chief Radhakrishnan will face CPM’s P R Natarajan in Coimbatore. This is the fifth time that Radhakrishnan has been fielded in Coimbatore, a BJP stronghold. While he won two consecutive Lok Sabha elections in 1998 and 1999, he was defeated in the 2004 and 2014 polls. Nainar Nagendran has been pitted against DMK’s IUML candidate K Nawaz Kani. While the party made a quick decision on candidates for four constituencies, Ramanathapuram delayed matters considering the keen contest for the seat among some senior leaders. Heatwave throws life out of gear in Patn.description: PATNA: With the mercury rising high, city residents are having a difficult time going out in the sun for their day-to-day business. Life has been thrown out of gear due to the heatwave prevailing across the state. While elderly people, homemakers and children are mostly staying indoors, people, who cannot skip office, can be seen travelling by cars, autos or cabs. Pedestrians, on the other hand, desperately search for shades to get some rest. Different juice stalls are also witnessing an increased footfall due to heat. A private firm executive, Manoj Kumar (32), who drinks juice at a stall on Boring Road said, “I need to keep myself hydrated during my office hours.” A number of parks in the city were vacant on Monday afternoon. Anand Kumar (25), who sells tickets at one of these parks, said, “People are not even coming for their regular morning walks. Those, who used to come on Sundays to spend time with their families, are staying at home.” A traffic police personnel at Income Tax roundabout, Brajesh Kumar Singh, told this reporter, “It is very difficult to manage traffic, especially during daytime. I drink a lot of water and wear a mask to protect myself from heatwave.” Quadragenarian Mahesh Kumar, a rickshaw-puller, faces a difficult time when the sun is up. “People do not want to walk in the heat and take a rickshaw even for covering a short distance,” Kumar said and added he could not stay indoors as this was his only source of income. Meanwhile, frequent power cuts and low voltage are adding up to the woes of Patnaites. Boring Road resident Akanksha Kumari (32) said, “It is unbearably hot and low voltage as well as power cuts are adding up to our difficulties.” Parents are not allowing their children to play outside. Anita Kumari (32), a resident of Rajiv Nagar, said, “My kids might fall ill while playing in the sun. Therefore, I tell them to play inside the house.” Kankerbagh resident Pranita Shekhar (28), who is a homemaker, does not want to go out to buy fruits and vegetables. “I only want to sit in front of the air conditioner,” she said. Even youths are avoiding to go out in the scorching heat. Loyola High School student Aman Singh (19) said, “I don’t make plans in which I have to face the sun. I have even shifted my coaching classes to the evening batch.” Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Experts visit Muzaffarpur hospital to fi.description: PATNA/MUZAFFARPUR: Health agencies and experts from across the country have started visiting Sri Krishna Medical College and Hospital (SKMCH) in Muzaffarpur again to find the cause of acute encephalitis syndrome (AES), which has claimed at least 107 lives this season and more than 1000 over the last one decade. Dr Gopal Shankar Sahni, head of paediatrics department at SKMCH, said several teams of experts and doctors from National Centre for Disease Control (NCDC), Delhi, National Institute of Virology (NIV), Pune, and All India Institutes of Medical Sciences (AIIMS) Delhi and Patna have come to Muzaffarpur to study the cases and find the cause of AES, which has been occurring during peak summer and pre-monsoon season in the north Bihar district since 1994-95. Incidentally, most of these agencies and organizations had conducted studies on the disease in the past as well. “They are taking blood, urine and throat sob samples of the affected children. Besides, they will be studying the profile of the victims and their food habits, common places of occurrence of the disease, among others,” Dr Sahni told TOI on Tuesday. He said researchers have so far failed to reach any conclusion. He attributed the disease to extreme heat and humidity. “The AES outbreak mostly happened when the maximum temperature remained above 38 degrees C and humidity was in the range of 60-70% and above,” he said. Patna-based Indira Gandhi Institute of Medical Sciences (IGIMS) doctor has suggested brain biopsy and tissue culture of the victims to know the cause of AES deaths. “Following the inspection of SKMCH by Union health minister recently, the state government had asked IGIMS to suggest steps for finding the cause of the disease. Based on a detailed study and deliberations on researches done by agencies across the globe on the disease in Muzaffarpur, we have recommended brain biopsy in death cases and brain tissue biopsy in case of fever,” IGIMS medical superintendent Dr Manish Mandal told TOI. He said majority of the researches have been based on blood samples only. Doctors at SKMCH, however, claimed the studies conducted in the past were not based on blood samples only. “The researches conducted by the NIV-Pune, NCDC and CDC-Atlanta between 2011 and 2013 were based on a number of samples, including blood, urine, cerebrospinal sasal fluid, rectal sob, nasal sob and throat secretin. NIV, in fact, had conducted even brain biopsy in one case. However, no virus was found to be the cause of the disease in any of the studies and viral encephalitis was ruled out. The studies put the disease in the category of non-inflammatory encephalopathy,” Dr Sahni said. On being asked why brain biopsy was not done in suspected AES cases, Dr Sahni said: “Biopsy and other forms of autopsies are done only in the case of unnatural deaths. However, the AES deaths are natural due to some disease,” he said. The other researches on the AES, locally known as ‘Chamki Bukhar (high fever with seizure)’, include those published in journals of Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) in Atlanta and The Lancet Global Health medical journal in 2017. Different studies and researches have blamed different causes of the disease, including malnourishment, binge-eating litchi on empty stomach and even heatstroke. Muzaffarpur-based Dr Arun Shah, who is a member of national executive committee of the Indian Paediatrics Association, said the CDC study had attributed the disease to acute hypoglycaemic encephalopathy, which is caused due to extreme low level of blood glucose in the body. “Under-nutrition is a common trend observed in most of the children suffering from the AES as they belong to poor families. The CDC, in its recommendations, had advised parents of the area not to allow their children to venture out in the orchards and feed them properly before going to sleep,” said Dr Shah. Parents of several victims also accepted under-nutrition. Nunu Mahto, who lost his 4-year-old son Prince on June 10 due to AES, said his son had consumed nothing on June 7 night. He was convulsing next morning. “We tried to admit him to Kanti primary health centre, but they did not respond. Finally, we took him to SKMCH where he died,” Nunu said. Chandrababu Naidu.description: KURNOOL: Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Friday launched a blistering attack on Andhra Pradesh chief minister and erstwhile ally N Chandrababu Naidu, calling him 'u-turn Babu', whose "intent" was not on state's development. Addressing a well-attended election rally here, he sought to reject Naidu's repeated attacks that his government neglected the state. Andhra Pradesh goes to siumultaneous elections to the 175-member assembly and 25 Lok Sabha seats in the first phase on April 11 with the BJP contesting them alone. Listing various initiatives taken by the NDA government for Andhra Pradesh, Modi said it was during his regime that the Vizag-Chennai industrial corridor was flagged off and approval for the first National Institute of Ocean Technology (NIOT) given. It was also the 'chowkidar' who cleared the first Indian Institute of Packaging (IIP) besides approving the greenfield petrochemical complex for the state, he said. "Five years ago, your one vote made me PM. Your Pradhan sewak worked selflessly day and night for the people of the country. Chowkidar kept the interest of the state in mind," he said. Modi also recalled that the NDA government sanctioned first central university in Anantpur. He accused Naidu, the Telugu Desam Party supremo, of pasting state government 'stickers' on the Central schemes. "For sure, I could have done more work. I just required the cooperation of the state government. I made all efforts from my side, but the person who is running the government (Naidu), his intention is not Andhra Pradesh's development," Modi said. Levelling charges of corruption and dynasty politics against Naidu, he said the election date of April 11 will usher in the "double engine" of the state's growth -- a BJP government both at the Centre and the state. There was debate going on in AP that there were 'schemes for corruption,' ranging from the creation of the new capital Amravati, the Prime Minister charged. "The people of Andhra Pradhesh know whose coffers are being filled.. when this chowkidar sought accounts, u-turn Babu took a u-turn from AP's growth and walked out from NDA," Modi lashed out. Naidu had snapped ties with the NDA in March last year, accusing the Centre of not honouring the "promised" special category status to Andhra Pradesh. Hitting out at the TDP supremo for getting close to the Congress, Modi said Naidu has "found friends who are on bail," apparently referring to Congress leaders Rahul Gandhi and Sonia Gandhi who are on bail in the National Herald case. Modi, who had in the past hit out at Naidu for alleged family politics, said the election should also see the "son set", and called for a new "sun rise." He deliberately stressed on the "son" part to drive home his point on dynasty politics targeting the AP chief minister and his son and state minister Nara Lokesh. Without elaborating, Modi mocked that Pakistan has now accepted Naidu's "friends" as "hero." Download The Times of India News App for Latest Elections News.

Cleanliness: DRM seeks passengers\u2019.description: PATNA: Making a departure from his daily routine work, Danapur divisional railway manager (DRM) Ranjan Prakash Thakur on Thursday travelled in the Patna-Pt Deendayal Upadhaya Junction MEMU passenger (63225) train along with other senior officials of the Danapur division to take the first-hand feedback from passengers about cleanliness inside the bogies and the problems faced by them in view of heatwave condition in the region. Thakur interacted with passengers and sought their cooperation in keeping the bogies neat and clean. He also checked running condition of fans and lights in the bogies. The DRM suggested the passengers to avail the facility of mobile tickets while travelling in short distance trains. The DRM said the newly introduced mobile ticket system has found many takers in the division. Earlier, Thakur inaugurated the newly-built railway officers’ rest house at Rajendra Nagar Terminal in presence of ECR GM L C Trivedi. The rest house has 12 rooms with modern facilities. Thakur asked the railway officials to replace the old water chilling plant at the Rajendra Nagar Terminal with a new one. At Patna Junction, the DRM inspected the renovation work of the main station building from the Mahavir Temple side. He asked the railway officials concerned to complete the wall painting work soon with the colour combination of white and gold. The DRM said two more escalators would be made functional at platform number 1 of Patna Junction. Meanwhile, normal traffic movement was restored on Patna-Pt Deendayal Upadhaya Junction mainline route following successful completion of the route relay interlocking (RRI) work at Danapur station on Thursday. However, speed limit for mail and express trains passing through Danapur station has been fixed at 50km per hour. The speed restriction will be lifted after a week after the new RRI system settles down, the DRM said, adding railways has now decided to carry out RRI work at Kiul station. ECR chief public relations officer Rajesh Kumar said the railways has incurred an expenditure of Rs 50 crore to complete the RRI work at Danapur station. “Altogether 125 motor points were used in the RRI work and 675 new glued joints made to ensure foolproof safety of passengers,” Kumar said, adding railways has also built about a 5.5km-long third line in the Danapur yard for safe movement of traffic in course of shunting and placement of rakes on the platforms. Heatstroke kills 30 more in Bihar.description: PATNA/NALANDA/NAWADA: The heatwave sweeping Bihar has claimed 30 more lives in the past 24 hours, taking the death toll to 112 on Wednesday. The latest deaths were reported from Aurangabad, Begusarai, Rohtas, Munger and Nawada districts. The toll is likely to increase as unofficial reports of heatstroke deaths are also coming in from Nalanda district. The death count hit the 112 mark, up from 83 on Tuesday, despite western and northern Bihar, including Patna, experiencing a slight fall in temperature due to thunderstorms and light showers. Aurangabad has been the worst-hit with 48 deaths so far, followed by Gaya (35), Nawada (15), four each in Rohtas and Munger, Begusarai (3), Jamui (2) and one death in Nalanda, said Bihar State Disaster Management Authority officials. With temperatures in several districts around 43 degrees Celsius, hospitals are inundated with people suffering from heatstroke. Schools in the state will remain closed until June 23. The number of deaths could rise as a large number of people are undergoing treatment in various hospitals, and some deaths, officials say, are likely to have gone unreported. With the heatwave death toll rising, the district administrations in Gaya, Aurangabad and Nawada have imposed Section 144 CrPc (illegal assembly) to stop people from going out. All labour-intensive work, including construction activities, has been banned between 11am and 4pm. Additional DM of Aurangabad, Sudhir Kumar, confirmed the 48 deaths reported in the district till Wednesday. “We have collected all data from government hospitals and primary health centres. Currently, nine patients suffering from heatstroke are undergoing treatment at the hospitals and PHCs,” Kumar said. The three district administrations, with the help of non-government organisations, have set up water kiosks for residents and anganbadi sevikas are distributing ORS sachets to people. Heatstroke deaths are also steadily rising in neighbouring Nalanda district with doctors claiming 10 deaths in the past four days, including three reported on Wednesday. One of them, a resident of a village under Islampur police station, died on the way to Biharsharif Sadar hospital after being referred by the local PHC, while a 56-year-old man from Amba village under Rahui police station area also died of heatstroke. According to unconfirmed reports, police also recovered the body of an unidentified woman from a field at Kadilpur village under Telhara police station area, who is suspected to have died of heatstroke. HC summons chief secy over ferry row.description: PATNA: The Patna high court on Thursday summoned the state chief secretary in a case pertaining to dispute over control of ferries in the state, which arose due to continuance of a 135-year-old British era Act. Certain provisions of The Bengal Ferries Act, 1885, which is still effective in the state, are in stark contrast to Bihar Land Reforms Act, 1950, which empowers village panchayats to manage ferries. According to the British era Act, ‘ferry’ includes a bridge of boats, pontoons or rafts, a swing-bridge, a flying bridge, a temporary bridge and a landing bridge. A special five-judge bench of the high court asked the chief secretary to appear before it on Monday after none from the state government turned up to assist the court on the issue during Thursday’s hearing. Like the Act, the writ petition in the case is also very old as it was filed by Rupauli Thana Naw Yatayat Sahyog Samiti way back in September 1988 over settlement of a wooden bridge known as Dobha ghat in Rupauli, Purnia. The bench of Chief Justice Amreshwar Pratap Sahi and Justices Chakradhari Sharan Singh, Ashutosh Kumar, Sudhir Singh and Rajeev Ranjan Prasad was hearing the matter for fourth time on Thursday. Either advocate general Lalit Kishore or additional advocate general (AAG) Khurshid Alam were to appear before it. However, none of them turned up even though the court waited for them for more than half-an-hour. Though AAG Anjani Kumar offered to assist the court on the issue, it did not work as the court had taken exception to the absence of advocate general and AAG Alam. During earlier hearings by the special bench, the chief secretary was asked to file a counter affidavit on the issue. On March 14, the court was not satisfied with the affidavit filed by the chief secretary and asked him to file an appropriate affidavit again. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

\nIPS Officers\u2019 Wives Association o.description: The IPS Officers’ Wives Association recently organised a Family Night for the officers and their better halves. The do, held at the lawns of the BMP campus, was a memorable event, with the venue being decked up in a Valentine theme with heart-shaped balloons. Upping the fashion quotient was Prity Singh Rana who looked pretty in her pink lehenga, while Poonam Thakur, president of the association, earned lots of compliments for her hairstyle and suit. “The purpose behind organising the event was to foster relationships and encourage family bonding activities,” said Poonam. “The bash gave us the opportunity to enjoy some moments of togetherness with our better halves, which we hardly enjoy because of our busy and hectic schedule,” said DGP PK Thakur. Madhurima Raj and Ratna added some spice to the evening by organising some interactive games for the guests. The paper dance had some fun moments, as the couples struggled to shake a leg on the sheet of paper given to them. Another fun-filled activity of the evening was when the husbands were asked to sing a song for their wives based on the items which they took out from a box, in which Sunit Kumar sung the song Ek Garam Chai Ki Pyaali. Later, all the guests moved to the dance floor. Kundan Krishnan and JS Gangawar were seen dancing on songs like Blue Eyes, India Waale and many more. Bihar villagers: \u2018We aren\u2019t st.description: MUZAFFARPUR: There isn't a villager, man or woman, in this part of Bihar who has not heard of the 'lychee deaths' or the theory that toxins in lychee could be the probable cause of death of over a hundred children in Bihar. And the villagers are exasperated with the media focus on "lychee deaths".  "When we know that lychees could kill our children, why would we let them eat them? Would we not be extra cautious to ensure that our children don't eat them?" asks Mohammed Zafrul, who sells chicken in Raksa village. Another interjects that it was possible that if both parents worked as labourers, unsupervised children, especially of those living near or working on the lychee orchards might have eaten the fruit. They insist, however, that cases of AES from their own village do not fall into this category. Mohammed Sharif Alam, who sells cloth in the village, lost his two-and-a-half-year old son to AES. "Seeing all the news of deaths and AES over the years supposedly caused by lychee, why would any parent allow their children to eat lychee?" asks Alam. "Neither do we live near lychee farms, nor is he old enough to go by himself or with other kids to get them from orchards," he adds.  There is general relief in the area that there were "only four deaths" on Thursday, a sign of just how fatalistic people have become when it comes to this annual scourge. They are all hoping the lower number of deaths on Thursday signals the beginning of the end of this year's spell of deaths from AES.  But villagers are miffed that people don't seem to believe them when they say, "forget lychee for children, we have stopped buying lychees even for adults or letting them eat lychees. We are just not willing to take that risk." While media has been highlighting the lack of awareness in the villages and arguing that awareness campaigns could have prevented the sudden spurt in AES cases, villagers are exasperated with 'experts' and the media refusing to accept that families no longer allow children to eat lychees.  Their own conviction is that the deaths have to do with the unrelenting heat. Meena chokes up and walks away asserting firmly that her daughter did have dinner the night before she was hospitalised.  Her five-year-old daughter Anushka is in the paediatric ICU of SKCHM with epilepsy and fever. And no, she did not have lychee but yes, she was playing in the sun the day before she fell ill. Meditation changing lives of prisoners i.description: PATNA: ‘Prison SMART Programme’, an initiative of Sri Sri Ravi Shankar’s Art of Living Foundation, is changing the lives of prisoners in state’s several jails. The programme includes eight-day yoga and meditation camp by professionals for the prisoners serving jail sentence across the state. Yoga sessions will also be held at these jails under the programme on International Yoga Day on Friday. As part of the programme, eight-day camps are being conducted in all the divisional and central jails since February this year. The prisoners learn and perform Sudarshan Kriya, Bhatrika Pranayam and meditation at the camp. Active participation by prisoners and their demand for organising yoga and meditation programmes frequently point to the will of the jail inmates to improve their livelihood. Yoga instructors Kaushik Kapuriya, Kumar Ranjaya, Utkarsh Kumar and Amar Kumar Sinha have successfully conducted the programme at central jails in Beur and Motihari and divisional jails at Bettiah, Begusarai, Siwan and Purnia. “The programme is supported by jail authorities. The initiative is aimed at promoting introspection among the prisoners and making them happy. Jail employees are also being trained by the foundation at the Bihar Institute of Correctional Administration at Hajipur,” IG (prison and correctional services) Mithilesh Mishra said. Meera Singh, a volunteer of Art of Living Foundation, said, “The Prison Smart Programme is for the betterment of prisoners. The inmates are also humans and they too deserve proper care. Yoga and meditation under the guidance of professional trainers will help the prisoners in searching new way of life.” Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Heatstroke kills 12 more, toll mounts to.description: PATNA: Twelve more people died of sunstroke in the state in the last 24 hours, following fresh causalities reported from Aurangabad, Begusarai, Gaya, Nalanda and Rohtas districts. As the heat wave gripped most parts of the state, the death toll due to the heatstroke surged to 124 on Thursday. Aurangabad alone witnessed the death of 49 people due to scorching heat with 31 new cases of heatstroke admitted in government hospitals and primary health centres on Thursday, according to figures realeased by the Bihar State Health Society, a wing of state health department. However, Aurangabad additional district magistrate Sudhir Kumar said that five deaths were reported on Thursday. “These suspected heatstroke patients were brought dead to government hospitals. Altogether 49 people have died in the district over the last four days, while eight patients were admitted on Thursday,” he said As per information provided by different departments of the state government, the toll due to heatwave in Gaya is 39, 14 in Nawada, seven in Rohtas, six in Begusarai, four in Munger and two in Nalanda. With the temperature hovering between 41 and 44 degree Celsius in most parts of the state, the number of patients suffering from heat ailments is increasing with each passing day. State health additional secretary Kaushal Kishore said altogether 120 patients were admitted to hospitals in Gaya, 57 in Nawada, 18 in Vaishali, five in Siwan, four in Samastipur, three each in Arwal and Jehanabad, two each in Saharsa and West Champaran, and one each in Bhojpur, East Champaran and Purnia. Section 144 CrPc has been imposed in Gaya, Aurangabad and Nawada as the death toll due to sunstroke is rapidly increasing. Under this section, all construction activities and assembly of people been banned from 11am to 4pm. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

H1B Visa news.description: WASHINGTON: The Trump administration has no plans to cap H-1B work visas for nations that force foreign companies to store data locally, the state department said on Thursday. Reuters reported on Wednesday that the United States had told India it was considering restricting the H-1B visa programmes for countries with the data storage requirement. The H-1B programme issues US visas to skilled foreign workers. US mulling 15% cap on H-1B visa for Indians"The Trump Administration has no plans to place caps on H-1B work visas for nations that force foreign companies to store data locally," a state department spokeswoman said in a statement in response to the Reuters article. While an administration's "Buy American Hire American" executive order calls for a broad review of US worker visa programs, including the H-1B programme, it was not targeted at a specific country, the spokeswoman said. It is "completely separate from our ongoing discussions with India about the importance of ensuring the free flow of data across borders," the spokeswoman added. Earlier on Thursday, India said it was in talks with the United States on H-1B visas, but foreign ministry spokesman Raveesh Kumar told a news conference: "We have not heard anything officially from the US government" on capping such permits for Indians. US secretary of state Mike Pompeo is scheduled to visit New Delhi next week for talks that will include areas of disagreement between the two countries over trade. H-1B cap for India? It’s not easy and may need approval by US Congress, say expertsTwo senior Indian officials told Reuters on Wednesday they had been briefed last week on a US plan to cap the number of H-1B visas given annually to Indians at between 10% and 15% of the total number issued. There is no country-specific limit on the 85,000 H-1B work visas the United States issues every year, and an estimated 70% of them go to Indians. Shiv Sena List 2019.description: MUMBAI: Shiv Sena has come up with it's first list of 21 candidates, out of 23 to contest in Lok Sabha polls in Maharashtra. Except Osmanabad, 17 sitting Sena MP's are part of the list, includes Mumbai, Thane, Kalyan, Raigad. Following complaints received by local functionaries from Osmanabad, the party has denied ticket to sitting MP Ravindra Gaikwad. Gaikwad, who had allegedly hit an Air India staffer with his slipper because he was refused a business class seat in March 2017. Maharashtra: Track here Lok Sabha elections' full coverageSena has kept two seats, Palghar and Satara, on hold, likely to announce on Sunday. Late Chintaman Wanga, former BJP MP's son Shrinivas likely to contest from Palghar on Sena ticket whereas former NCP legislator Narendra Patil may might contest as Sena candidate from Satara. Patil met Shiv Sena president Uddhav Thackeray on Friday at Matoshree. Other candidates are: South Mumbai: Arvind Sawant; South Central Mumbai: Rahul Shewale; Mumbai North West: Gajanan Kirtikar; Kalyan: Shrikant Shinde; Raigad: union minister Anant Gite; Osmanabad: Omraje Nimbalkar, Ratnagiri-Sindhudurg: Vinayak Raut; Kolhapur-Sanjay Mandlik; Hatkanangle: Dhairyasheel Mane; Nashik: Hemant Godse; Shirdi: Sadashiv Lokhande; Shirur: Shivajirao Adhalrao Patil; Aurangabad: Chandrakant Khaire; Yavatmal Washim: Bhawana Gawli; Buldana: Prataprao Jadhav; Ramtek: Kripal Tumane; Amrawati-Anandrao Adsul, Parbhani: Sanjay Jadhav; Maval: Shrirang Barne; Hingoli: Hemant Patil. Over 30 families leave Bihar village aft.description: HAJIPUR (VAISHALI): Harivanshpur, a sleepy hamlet under Bhagwanpur block in Vaishali district, has suddenly hogged the national limelight. The village, around 25 km north of the district headquarters town Hajipur, has already lost 10 children due to Acute Encephalitis Syndrome (AES), which has acquired alarming proportions across the state. More than 30 families, mostly belonging to the fishermen community, have abandoned their homes and shifted to their relatives’ houses out of fear of the deadly brain fever, also called ‘chamki bukhar’. Only old ones, widows or those who can’t walk due to physical disability are in the village having a population of around 600. The village, once humming with activities, now wears a deserted look. Big locks can be found hanging at the doors of most of the houses in the village. One Chaturi Sahni, (45), a resident of the village, said on Thursday, “I have lost two members of my family due to the AES. My wife Chanchal Devi is speechless ever since she lost her two kids within 24 hours. It’s a double shocker for the family. She has stopped taking meal ever since the incident happened.” Sahni, a cook by profession, however, blamed the district administration in particular and the state government in general for his two sons’ death. “I had no money to take my seven-year-old son and another 18 month-old them to the sadar hospital at Hajipur after their condition deteriorated. I had to take loan from my brother Sushil Sahni to hire an auto-rickshaw to take both my ailing sons to the hospital for treatment. But none of them survived. While Sahni was busy in preparation for the funeral of his elder son, the news about his second son’s death came. Two deaths at short intervals have virtually shaken the family from within. Later, I decided to shift my family to my in-laws house at neighbouring Bilanpur village in Vaishali district out of fear,” he added. The ordeal of another resident Rajesh Kumar (34), is far from over. “I have lost my seven-year-old son Shravan Kumar. I decided to shift my family to my relative’s house due to apprehension of losing my second son, who is only three-and-a half-years old. I have suggested my wife to stay there for a few weeks till the situation improves,” Rajesh, who is a farmer, said. Ahilya Devi (40) is so shocked that she only stares at the visitors. “Kee hoyale hayee. Gaon mein bheer kahe hayee (What has happened? Why so many people are here?),” she asked her nephew Santosh Sahni. Santosh (25) tried to convince her that everything is fine and there is nothing to worry. Locals said that more than 10 children below the age of 10 are still undergoing treatment either at Hajipur sadar hospital or SKMCH in Muzaffarpur. Vaishali district magistrate Rajiv Raushan, however, confirmed the death of only six children from Harivanshpur village. “We are aware of the tragedy, which struck the village. The officials of the district administration are camping there and keeping a close watch. A medical team is also camping in the village. Besides, an ambulance has been provided to take the patients to the hospital,” he added. Potable water is being supplied to the village through tankers. Sanitation work has also started and people are being made aware about the AES by Asha workers. Prohibitory orders under section 144 have already been clamped asking people to avoid moving out in the scorching sun between 11 pm and 5 pm. Schools, colleges and other educational institutes have been closed as a precautionary measure, the DM said. In addition, ORS packets are being distributed among the residents of the village. The DM said that three blocks—Bhagwanpur, Vaishali and Lalganj—which are close to Muzaffarpur, have been identified as worst hit. Till date 15 deaths have been reported from the district. However, one case each from Mahua, Janadaha and Chehrakalan blocks have also been reported, he added. Block-level officials have been directed to launch sanitation work on a priority basis. “People are being made aware of the hygienic condition,” the DM said. On the other hand, a senior official said that some of the parents turned up with their kids for medical examination on Thursday. But they left for their relatives houses soon after the check up in the village. The officials tried to convince them to stay in their houses but in vain. “Abhi yahan rahne mein jaan ko kahtra hai (Life is under threat now),” one of the residents told the official. Rahul Gandhi.description: NEW DELHI: Strongly indicating that he does not intend to review his decision to step down as Congress president after the party's Lok Sabha debacle, Rahul Gandhi on Thursday said the party would decide on his successor and he would keep himself aloof from the process. Asked by the media in the Parliament complex about his possible successor, Rahul crucially did not parry the question but answered that he was not the person to decide on the issue and that it was a task for the party. After weeks of anonymous claims, this was the first confirmation of his intent to quit as the AICC chief ever since he announced the decision at a closed-door meeting of the Congress Working Committee (CWC) on May 25. While the apex body turned down the resignation, Congress insiders said that Rahul is insistent on leaving the top job and had rebuffed all attempts to persuade him to stay on. Lok Sabha poll fallout: Congress considers naming interim presidentEven before Rahul publicly declared his intent, there were indications that Congress was considering naming a working president or interim president at the head of a "collegium" of leaders. Names of veterans like Mallikarjun Kharge, Sushilkumar Shinde, Ashok Gehlot, Mukul Wasnik and Prithviraj Chavan have done the rounds as likely candidates. Rahul's insistence that no one from the Gandhi family should hold the post effectively rules out sister Priyanka. Take charge, douse fire in Cong: Moily tells Rahul GandhiRahul's brief remark comes at a time when the party is caught in a bitter blame-game with its data department under Praveen Chakraborty in the crossfire for "misleading" the leadership on the trends in the Lok Sabha elections. The attack has been sharp with allegations that the data itself was not reliable with Chakraborty's proximity to Rahul raising the question whether the "feedback" only served to strengthen the leader's inclination to target PM Narendra Modi's image. Meanwhile, Rahul met Chhattisgarh CM Bhupesh Baghel along with AICC state in-charge P L Punia for a political discussion on Thursday evening. Party leaders attach importance to the meeting given that he has been reluctant to interact with colleagues lately. However, Rahul's public attestation about quitting may make it difficult for AICC managers to sway his thinking. As it became apparent that he might actually refuse to relent, various proposals have been mooted to make decision-making a collective affair through a "collegium" so that Rahul returns to active presidency. There have also been suggestions that a working president could be appointed. The proposal for a collegium is rooted in Rahul's complaint that he has been working alone and the party leaders did not pull their weight behind him in the LS polls. He had aired his grievances at the now-famous CWC brainstorming called after the party failed to improve its performance, going from 44 to 52. However, Congress leaders said they would continue to make efforts to persuade Rahul. Rajasthan CM Ashok Gehlot told TOI, "Rahul has to remain the Congress president. He worked hard and fearlessly. Victory and defeat are part of polls." Gehlot warned if Rahul quits, Congress workers would either become inactive or leave the party.Sources say Rahul is hell-bent on quitting and has made it clear that none from the Gandhi family should be put at the helm of the Congress organisation. Tamil Nadu Elections.description: Voting for Lok Sabha elections 2019 in Tamil Nadu will take place in a single phase on April 18 as per the notification issued by the Election Commission of India. The counting of votes will take place on May 23. | Lok Sabha elections 2019: Get all live updatesThe four-cornered contest for the 39 Lok Sabha seats features AIADMK-led National Democratic Alliance (NDA), its chief rival DMK-led Secular Progressive Alliance (SPA), actor Kamal Haasan's Makkal Needhi Maiam and TTV Dhinakaran's Amma Makkal Munnetra Kazhagam (AMMK). Out of the 39 seats in the state, seven Lok Sabha seats are reserved for SC. The constituencies reserved for SC candidates are Thiruvallur, Kancheepuram, Villupuram, Nilgiris, Chidambaram, Nagapattinam and Tenkasi in Tamil Nadu. | Tamil Nadu Lok Sabha elections: Get all live updatesIn the last Lok Sabha polls, AIADMK had a vote share of 44.3 per cent by winning 37 seats. BJP had a vote share of 5.5 per cent by winning just 1 seat, while NDA managed to win two seats with a vote share of 18.5 per cent PMK won one seat and had a vote share of 4.4 per cent. BJP (NDA) had an alliance with PMK. DMK was not able to win on any seat in the last Lok Sabha polls. In Lok Sabha elections 2019, DMK is contesting on 20 seats, while the Congress is fighting elections on 9 seats in Tamil Nadu. In the AIADMK-BJP alliance, the national party will be contesting from five seats in the state while the PMK will be contesting from seven. Air India to start direct flight from Pa.description: PATNA: Air India is set to launch a direct flight from Patna to Amritsar from September 27. This announcement was made by Union civil aviation minister Hardeep Singh Puri on his Twitter account on Monday. The tweet read, “To honour another long pending demand of devotees to provide air connectivity between Guru Nagri & Sri Patna Sahib, I am delighted to announce the commencement of a daily @airindiain flight between Mumbai-Patna-Amritsar from 27th Sept 2019 (sic).” Jayaprakash Narayan International (JPNI) Airport’s assistant general manager (air traffic management) Santosh Kumar told this newspaper on Tuesday that the airline operators had not yet sought permission for or notified about the commencement of the new flight to Amritsar. Santosh said, “Air India has been allotted time slot for a new flight between Patna and Bokaro as part of the summer schedule of the Patna airport. However, since recarpeting of the runway at Bokaro airport is going on, it will take some time for the airline to start the flight.” According to Air India executives, the timing for Mumbai-Patna-Amritsar has not been decided yet. “At present, there is no direct flight from Patna to Amritsar. So, we expect the new one to be a hit among flyers. Bookings will begin from July and the fare is likely to be lower than other connecting flights,” an executive said. Boring Canal Road resident Anu Johar, who has relatives in Amritsar, hailed the decision. “It takes a lot of time to reach Amritsar and the fare is quite high. I am waiting for the direct flight to be launched,” she said. Sunny Singh, who runs a souvenir shop at Takhat Sri Harmandir Ji Patna Sahib Gurdwara, often visits Amritsar with his family. He said, “I am happy that Air India will start a direct flight to Amritsar.” At present, the Patna airport handles 45 arrivals and departures each from 7.10am to 9.40pm every day. It has direct air connectivity with 11 cities, including Ahmedabad, Allahabad, Bengaluru, Kolkata, Chennai, Hyderabad, Lucknow, Mumbai, New Delhi, Ranchi and Shamsabad. Bihar: 7 more die from AES, toll rises t.description: MUZAFFARPUR/BHAGALPUR: With the deaths of seven more kids in the state, the acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) toll on Wednesday went up to 121 on Friday. Of the seven deaths, three were reported from Bhagalpur and the rest occurred in AES epicentre Muzaffarpur. Even as the death count continued to rise, a TOI front page report on Thursday highlighting the poor state of public health centres (PHCs) in Muzaffarpur prompted the executive director of Bihar State Health Society, Manoj Kumar, visited various PHCs in the district to take stock of the facilities, including availability of doctors and other staff. Kumar expressed satisfaction over the facilities available at the PHCs, but pulled up doctors posted at the Meenapur community health centre and warned them of action if they failed to carry out their responsibilities. While visiting the Meenapur CHC, he directed the medical officer to ensure that not a single patient should reach SKMCH in Muzaffarpur without being referred by the local hospital. “Search to find kids afflicted with AES must be intensified with the help of Asha, Aanganwadi and Jeevika workers. Assistance of non-governmental organisations, working in the field of healthcare can also be taken taken,” Kumar said. Meanwhile, Muzaffarpur DM Alok Ranjan Ghosh on Thursday evening issued a medical bulletin informing the deaths of three more children at the SKMCH and one at Kejriwal Matri Sadan. “Three deaths at SKMCH have raised the AES death toll to 98 — another child died at the privately-run Kejriwal hospital, where the total number of casualties have reached 20. Altogether 552 children have been admitted to the hospitals so far, out of which 178 are still undergoing treatment,” the medical bulleting said. At Bhagalpur, R C Mandal, medical superintendent at Jawaharlal Nehru Medical College and Hospital confirmed the three deaths due to AES and said one child was undergoing treatment at the ICU. “We have geared up our resources at JLNMCH. Altogether 30 beds in the air-conditioned ICU, NICU and PICU have been reserved for AES patients,” Mandal said. Bhagalpur civil surgeon Vijay Kumar Singh said leaves of doctors and paramedics at sub-divisional hospitals, PHCs and referral hospitals have been cancelled in the backdrop of AES deaths. Pawan Kalyan.description: GUNTUR: Stating that they will bulldoze bastions of TDP and YSR Congress, Janasena president Pawan Kalyan promised to grant Rs 5,000 pension to all farmers in the state. He said they will also grant Rs 8,000 crop incentive to farmers soon after coming into power in the next elections. Pawan further said his government would provide six to 10 LPG cylinders free-of-cost to each family every year. and also promised to fill 3 lakh vacancies in the government departments to provide jobs to youth. Addressing a meeting in Guntur on Monday, Pawan said that the future of the state did not mean the future of Lokesh and Jagan but it was the future of the people. “The space on the state’s political stage is not TDP’s and YSRC’s property as youth and women are eager to bring change through Jana Sena.” “TDP had lost moral right to rule the state as chief minister N Chandrababu Naidu had no control over his legislators who indulged in illegal activities,” Pawan said adding that he jumped into the political arena to bring in a change in the lives of commoners. “We supported TDP and BJP in the last elections with a hope to transform the state. Unfortunately, both of them have shattered our dreams,” he said. “Guntur city has been left in a lurch despite located a few kilometres away from the capital city. The entire city has been dug out in the guise of laying underground drainage scheme and left without repair. How shocking it is to see 30 people dying of diarrhoea in a city like Guntur? Is it not the failure of the state government? Opposition leader Jaganmohan Reddy is equally responsible for the tragedy as he never dared to question the government by going to the assembly,” he said. He further said they would construct apartments exclusively for Muslims in the city. He appealed to people to support his candidates Chandrasekhar (Guntur West), Zia-Ur-Rehman (East) and MP candidate Bonaboina Srinivas Yadav in the elections, Pawan said they fielded a BC candidate Srinivasa Yadav whereas TDP and YSRC both have given tickets to their own communities. Lok Sabha Poll 2019.description: LUCKNOW: With electioneering for the 2019 Lok Sabha polls gaining steam in Uttar Pradesh, political leaders are increasingly resorting to personal attacks on their adversaries. If the maverick BJP MLA from Bairia, Surendra Singh hit the headlines for his remarks against BSP supremo Mayawati, Uttar Pradesh cabinet minister Shrikant Sharma hit a new low by making indecent comments on Congress chief Rahul Gandhi. The Bairia MLA had said Mayawati gets facials done and her hair coloured even though she is 60-years-old. He also reportedly made offensive remarks against UPA chairperson Sonia Gandhi and Haryanvi singer-dancer Sapna Chaudhary, evoking widespread criticism from political parties and social media users. A media agency quoted him as saying that both Sonia Gandhi and Sapna Chaudhary used to work as dancers. "Rahul's mother (Sonia Gandhi) was also in the same profession in Italy and his father made her his own. He (Rahul Gandhi) should also take the family tradition forward and make Sapna his own," the MLA said. The BJP legislator, who is known for his controversial statements, had earlier termed Rahul Gandhi and his sister Priyanka Gandhi Vadra "Ravana and Shurpanakha", and accused Mayawati of "murdering" a woman's dignity by joining hands with one-time arch rival Samajwadi Party. UP Power Minister Shrikant Sharma stirred up a hornet's nest with his tweet terming the Congress president a "coward and impotent". The comments triggered a war of words between the two parties as well as on social media platform. Firebrand Uttar Pradesh chief minister Yogi Adityanath also finds mention in the list of leaders accused of making personal remarks against political rivals. He recently termed Congress candidate from Saharanpur, Imran Masood, the son-in-law of Jaish-e-Mohammed chief Azhar Masood. Addressing a rally in Saharanpur on Sunday, Adityanath said, "The son-in-law of Azhar Masood has entered the constituency and he speaks the language of the terror mastermind. "You people have to ensure that the person who speaks the language of Azhar Masood is defeated in the Lok Sabha elections," he said while seeking votes for BJP candidate from Saharanpur, Raghav Lakhanpal. Union minister and BJP MP Mahesh Sharma referred to Rahul Gandhi as 'Pappu' and his sister Priyanka Gandhi as 'Pappu ki Pappi' during a poll campaign in Gautam Buddh Nagar. Rahul Gandhi has often been mocked by the BJP and his opposition as 'Pappu', a colloquial sneer. "Pappu kehta hai main prime minister banunga Mayawati, Akhilesh Yadav, Pappu.. aur ab 'Pappu ki Pappi' bhi aa gayi hai. Wo Priyanka kya pehle hamare desh ki beti nahi thi kya, Congress ki beti nahi thi kya, aage nahi rahegi kya? kya naya leke aayi hai?" the minister told a crowd of his supporters on March 16. The quotes loosely translate to "Pappu says he wants to become prime minister. Mayawati, Akhilesh Yadav, Pappu ... and now 'Pappu's Pappi' has also arrived. Wasn't Priyanka already a daughter of this nation, a daughter of the Congress? And would she not remain so in future? What new has she brought in?" Most PHCs lack basic infra: Kin of AES v.description: MUZAFFARPUR: The acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) has proved a nightmare for several villages in Muzaffarpur and its neighbouring districts where people have seen their children dying due to brain fever over the past two decades. Dariapur in Kanti block of Muzaffarpur has dalit and mahadalit population. It has been one of the worst affected villages in the district. The village with a population of hardly 3000 people lacks basic infrastructure even when the government claims all-round development up to hamlets level. Subodh Paswan, whose daughter Nidhi (5) died due to AES earlier this month, blamed lack of medical facilities at local public health centre (PHC). “We took Nidhi to the PHC but they refused to admit her and referred her to SKMCH where she was declared dead. The doctors at SKMCH said her life could have been saved had she been brought a bit earlier,” Paswan said. Sanjay Kumar, another resident of Dariyapur, said the PHC remains open only for three to four days in a month. “Complaints have been lodged with the block officials, but in vain,” he added. Similar was the situation in Damodari, Ramur Sah and other villages from where majority of the AES cases have been reported. Most villagers are either daily wagers or agricultural labourers. Most children seldom go to the nearby Anganwadi centres as they remain open for hardly a couple of days in a month. So, they are deprived of nutritional foods supposed to be distributed through these centres. People have now started preventing their kids from going out in scorching heat, fearing fatal consequences. Even children and parents from urban pockets are apprehensive about the disease. “We are not sure whether this disease will affect our children or not as no urban locality has been hit by AES so far. We are taking precautionary measures and have asked our children not to go out in scorching heat unless necessary,” said Prabhakar Kumar, a resident of Brahmin Toli under the Town police station area of Muzaffarpur. But, in rural areas of the district, every second family is afraid of getting their ward sick and keeps children indoors. “We try our best to not let our wards move out during day time. We are also trying to ensure that our children must not go to the litchi orchards,” said Sakal Paswan of Dariapur Kafen under the Kanti police station area. Also, the tall claims of district health officials of providing manpower and infrastructure to the PHCs and additional PHCs along with referral hospitals of the district seem hollow as majority of the 16 PHCs are reeling from acute shortage of medical experts, nursing staff, apart from beds and other facilities, including medicines. The deadly disease, which was first reported in Bihar at Muzaffarpur in 1994-95, has spread its wings to neighbouring districts of Sitamarhi, Sheohar, East Champaran, West Champaran, Vaishali and Samastipur as well.
